Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2020 IEEE North American School for Information Theory(NASIT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The 2020 IEEE North American School for Information Theory (NASIT ’20) will be held at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, Canada, from July 8th to July 10th, 2020. This award supports travel expenses for US graduate students attending the school. These participants benefit by learning from senior colleagues, presenting their own research in poster sessions, and expanding their network with their community, as well as honing professional development skills.<br/><br/>The IEEE North American School for Information Theory is an annual event of the IEEE Information Theory Society; this will be the school's seventh year of operation. The School provide a supportive environment where foundations for learning and long-term future scientific collaborations are established. The School delivers interactive education for graduate students in the mathematical, engineering, and computer science aspects espoused by modern information theory, and offers students the opportunity to meet with and learn from senior researchers from academia and industry who present long-format tutorials. Student participants present their own research results in poster sessions. The IEEE Information Theory Society “Padovani Lecture” is delivered at the school.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Each year the IEEE Information Theory Society holds a North American School of Information Theory (NASIT) to help graduate students working on problems in information theory across the continent and the world come together to learn about the latest research frontiers in information theory and to form a community across the many universities. NASIT 2022 was held as a fully in-person event at UCLA from Aug. 15th to Aug. 20, 2022. Outdoor dining was used for all meals; masking was mandatory in the auditorium. It was attended by a total of 112 participants, including 81 graduate students (from across the U.S. and Canada) and 18 speakers. This award supported part of the on-campus housing costs and travel expenses for student participants. NASIT 2021 was a fully virtual event at UBC from June 21 to Jun 25, 2021, which did not incur any travel expenses.

NASIT 2022 included 6 half-day tutorials delivered by the leading information theory researchers, covering a wide range of topics such as active testing and learning, group testing with community correlations, the discovery of polar codes, learning distributions and robust estimation, information bottlenecks in distributed systems, and asymptotic equipartition property for graph matching. All of the tutorials videos and slides were posted on the NASIT 2022 website. In addition, the school included an overview of the NSF in information theory, followed by various panel discussions: young faculty on academic careers, industry internships and careers in information theory, and industrial researchers on how information theory is used for future 6G technology. The program also featured poster sessions where each graduate student attendee presents about their current research or an interesting area of information theory. As an exciting break, NASIT attendees spent an afternoon to visit the Los Angeles Getty Center.
